plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Petrobras conference call to discuss the Second Quarter 2011 Results. At this time, all lines are in a listen-only mode. Later, there will be a question-and-answer session and instructions will be given at that time. . As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.

Today, with us we have Mr. Almir Guilherme Barbassa, Petrobras CFO and Investor Relations Officer, and his staff. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Theodore Helms, Investor Relations Executive Manager of Petrobras, who has some additional comments. Please go ahead, Mr. Helms.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our conference call to discuss second quarter and 2011 results. We have a simultaneous webcast on the Internet that can be accessed at the site www.petrobras.com.br/ri/english.

Before proceeding, I'd like to draw your attention to the Slide 2. We may make forward-looking statements which are identified by use of the words will, expect and similar that are based on the beliefs and assumptions of Petrobras management and on information currently available to the company.

Finally, let me mention that this conference call will discuss Petrobras' results prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards, IFRS, and Brazilian legislation. At this moment, we are unable to discuss any issues related to U.S. GAAP results.

The conference call will be conducted by our CFO, Mr. Almir Guilherme Barbassa. He will comment on the company's operating and financial highlights and the main events during this quarter, and he will be available to answer any questions you may have.
Almir, please begin.

Good morning, good afternoon to everyone. Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss second quarter results. Reviewing a few of the highlights, quarterly net income was sequentially flat, about 32% higher year over year. Brazilian market continues to grow at a rapid pace with demand up 9% from a year ago and 19% in rest of the year. With Santos pre-salt (2:30) the first well of Lula's Pilot produced 36,000 Boe per day and we have initiated three new extended well tests in (2:44).

We successfully released our five-year plan which maintains the same level of CapEx but with greater percentage outstanding dedicated to upstream activity, particularly the pre-salt. We will also begin our 13 billion divestment program to better allocate our resources. In June, Moody's upgraded Petrobras from Baa1 to A3 reflecting the strength of our balance sheet and cash flow and the profitability opportunities that lay before us in the future.

Looking at the key indicators, operating income for the second quarter was down 4% sequentially while net income was flat. Our 1% decline in production by growing the net market higher cost for imported product and a strengthening real were the most important factors in determining our results. Year over year, quarterly operating income was (4:10) net income was up 32 (4:16).

Production. The year-over-year production in the first half of the year was up 2% as expected. First- half production was below our 2011 annual target of 2.1 million barrels per day due to higher scheduled maintenance and planned maintenance and the small delays in the start-up of some new wells also contributed to lower production in the first half.

Natural gas production is up 7% from last year as production capacity is now in place to meet growing Brazil demand for gas. Additional production (5:13) primarily LNG. Our international production declined by 5% primarily due to the schedules and of the cost (5:25) for our Nigerian production.

Additionally, we concluded our operations in Ecuador. The ramp-up of DT7 (5:34) which was 180,000 barrels per day capacity and which produced 72,000 barrels per day in the second quarter and this is (5:53) with 100,000 barrels per day capacity which began producing on Monday are expected, together with the Lula Pilot to be the principal driver of growth in the second half. By the end of the year, we expect to reach our peak production of 2,250,000 barrels per day. We will resume our daily average of 2.1 million barrels per day of oil in Brazil plus or minus 2.5% for 2011.

Since 1980, our compounded annual growth rate has been 10% as shown in this slide. Sometimes growth has been slower, other times faster, but the average has been 10%. Our history has been to grow by finding new oil reserves, new frontiers that we buy advancing the technologies and know-how. As we have transitioned from onshore to offshore and from shallow water to deep water, there has been times when growth was less than 10%.

When development is fully underway in the new frontier, growth accelerates. The pre-salt will be a repeat of our past. We are expanding into a new frontier. This takes time. Some of the resource now dedicated pre-salt have increased current production. But we are now beginning to see the results of our efforts in the pre-salt. As we ramp up production from these highly production and huge reserve wells (8:13) starting with fixing (8:20) under construction, we are highly confident that we can exceed the 10% growth rate of the past, producing 4.9 million barrels per day in 2012.

Update of pre-salt. This brings us to our (8:48) pre-salt. We have drilled a total of 30 wells to date and expect to have drilled another five at the end of the year. Currently in pre-salt drilling, in the pre-salt launch there are currently three systems produced in the area, the Lula Pilot and this lower path of producing the extended well pass in Guará and Lula Nordeste.

The development of pre-salt – when we created our market plan for the development of the pre-salt, we divided the development into three stages. First we have Phase 0, responding to exploration and operations, Phase 1a which is development phase based on known technology and practice and phase 1b which is the application of new technologies we expect to happen out there.
Phase 0 is fully underway with Lula Pilot and two systems capable of producing extended well tests. All the units contemplated in phase 1a are either under construction or being contracted.
This includes four large pilots under construction to be delivered in tranches, '12 and '13 and the other two (10:37). The well (10:42) controls are also now under construction.

Finally to develop the (10:48) barrels, we recently acquired four (10:49) and have leased the Inhaúma Shipyard (11:01). But Petrobras is committed to developing the local industry to supply the offshore oil industry in Brazil. The greatest efficiency can be achieved by having local suppliers who are committed with our needs located adjacent to our operations. But for the industry to be sustainable, it must be competitive in quality, cost and (11:32).

(11:37) and design of the concession terms, the regulatory system and Petrobras policies. Developing a local industry required careful planning, proper incentives and perhaps, most importantly, time. Along these lines, you can see that local content requirements have successfully (12:02) in these grounds. As you can also see, many of the projects that will be developed over next five years were acquired in the early parts where the local contents requirement was less.

This gives us the flexibility and time to develop a competitive local industry while meeting the contractual terms of each concession, and present bids for these as their source comparison and other top side equipment. We are receiving internationally competitive bids in each and search try (12:37) for local content from the supplier increases over time.

What makes Petrobras and the development of the local industry so unique is that it is in a cost term freighted (12:57) area with huge, huge coverage, deploying technologies that had been evolving over 20 years.

These conditions give us the ability to understand each comparison (13:13) and plans for our needs for the long-term horizon. We can use our experience to create incentive for local investments by suppliers, such as standardization, the scale and long term pay hole agreements.

Looking at the prices. Given that in the international price for oil during the last year is obviously an important factor in our results. In the last nine months the price of Brent (13:54), which impacts both revenue and costs, have increased by $40 per barrel. Due to our operating policy of minimizing price volatility in the Brazilian market, increased international price was not fully reflected in the domestic price.

During the second quarter of 2011, the average realization price for all our products sold was $105 per barrel versus an average price in the U.S. of $122 per barrel for the same basket of products. Our pricing policy remains to pull international volatility (14:42) over the major carriers. As we have done since through the regulation of the Brazilian market at the beginning of 2002.
Looking at the lifting costs. During the quarter, lifting costs for abutment (15:10) increased by 10% in reais, and 15% in dollars. This follows upon similar increase during the first quarter.
Our systems in Campos Basin are maturing, which require additional maintenance that is reflected in lifting cost. Lower production from scheduled and unscheduled maintenance added to the cost.

Also the high cost of oil and gas to raise the cost of third party services, material and other charges. In the last six months, oil price increased by $30 per barrel, while lifting cost increased by approximately $15 per barrel. During the last 10 years, our lifting cost have historically averaged 10% of our realization price for a barrel of oil, so this latest increase is consistent with past experience. Production taxes also rose by $5 a barrel as a result of the higher value of our oil, which is based on international benchmarks.

Demand for petroleum derivatives in Brazil continues to exceed the GDP growth. The growth is driven by gains in real income, gasoline, petroleum, (16:49) due to price differentials and increasing due to using Brazilian roughly due with (16:57) other industry. To meet growth, we are investing to capture margins and produce more of the what the market requires.

We are now seeing the results: capacity utilization of 92% was at all time highs with our headwind of (17:20) domestic oil, which is 81% of throughput. Production of diesel (17:26) and gasoline has increased while outputs for fuel oil has been reduced. The combined impact has been to produce higher volume products while reducing the logistical cost of importing and exporting oil and products.

Natural gas consumption for several SKUs continues to grow up by 8% year-over-year. For non-thermal use, the growth was 8% year-over-year. Thermol demand was literally unchanged and with the hydraulic operation, our lateral scorings (18:22) were actually above normal, thermal escalation is in the second semester is not expected to materially increase. Our increase in gas demand was satisfied by domestic production which have much better margins relatively to import gas.

Turning to financial results. Revenue for the second quarter were up slightly from the prior quarter due to higher domestic sales, volumes and exports at a higher price. The increases in revenue were largely offset by higher cost of imports, higher production taxes and higher lifting and refining costs.

Expense increased by R$528 million with higher exploration expense and inventory adjustments, at least all items (19:33) believing to increased. As a result of these factors, operating income declined by 4% when compared with the first quarter, while EBITDA of R$16.1 million was stable.

Net financial results increased by R$873 million from the prior quarter as a result of the devaluation of the dollar and its impact on liability that are linked to the dollar. Higher income from cash and equivalents also contributed to the gains. This increase was primarily offset by deducting the earnings of non-controlled subsidiary generated largely by exchange gains from dollars liability. As a consequence of lower operating income, partially offset by higher income from monetized assets, net income was flat from the prior quarter.

Operating income for E&P in Brazil increased by 13% as a result of higher price. Partially offsetting the benefit of higher price was a small decrease in production and the higher lifting cost, particularly those associated with production tax. We ordered gas, oil, live urea (21:20) results of higher exploration and bright flow extend (21:23). The downstream segment experienced an operating loss of R$2.6 million in the first quarter versus an operating loss of near R$500 million in the prior quarter.

Downstream revenues increased due to the higher export price, higher volume and higher price for domestic products that track international price. Cost of goods sold increased as a result of higher price for crude oil feedstock and imported products, which increased faster than the products sold in Brazil. Refining cost increased by R$1.2 per barrel or slightly less than $1. Program maintenance was responsible for 58% of the cost increase.

In the first half of 2011, we performed 61% of the planned maintenance versus only 37% last year. With much of the maintenance behind us here, we expect refining costs to be lower for the rest of the year, material companies (22:53) and chemicals account for much of the remaining cost increase. The growing complexity of our system, particular, to remove sulfur was largely responsible for this increase.

The Gas & Power segment results improved due to higher sales volume of natural gas, and better margins as low cost from natural gas due to more expensive imported gas. Electric generation was lower, but in the future (23:33) at least the exports to us have seen improved margin and have increased income.

International operating income declined as a result of lower production, due primarily to the end of gas (23:48) volume from our Nigerian production. Income from our Distribution segment was lower by increasing volumes due to lower margin.

CapEx. Capital spending totaled R$32 billion during the first half of the year. Since 2011 (24:12), a decline of 16% from the first half of 2010. The first capital expenditure (24:20) last year saw the completion of a number of large projects, which have year-over-year comparison. Also, the profit (24:31) appreciation of the real contributed to lower level to import to standing plant level gas and paid or (24:45) in dollars lower when expressed in real. Finally, excess rain caused construction delays on the Campos (24:59) refinery and Comperj refinery in the first half.
Investment is starting to pick up in the second half of the year, with this budget cycle. (25:09).

We continue to have a very comfortable position with respect to both liquidity and leverage. For the past year we have maintained our net debt to net capital of 17%, while the net debt to EBITDA remained as of 1st May (25:45) time.

Cash and cash equivalents, including government securities with maturities above 90 days, were R$59.5 billion as of June 30. Our integrated model and pricing policy allows us to maintain stable cash flows, even in a declining oil market. This gives us the confidence that we can maintain our strength of our cash flow and balance sheet in these uncertain times.
With that overview, we will now be happy to answer any questions.
Thank you. . Our first question comes from Paul Cheng of Barclays Capital. Please go ahead.

Good morning, guys. Almir, two questions. One on the CapEx, first half you did R$32 billion. Your budget is a revised budget, the lower one is about 85. So if we base on the run rate I would suggest you need to do about R$26.4 billion a quarter in the second half comparing to the first half about R$16 billion. What's the likely that you're actually going to even hit opposed to the revised budget? Or should we assume that you're going to be at least about 10% below that level?

Paul, Petrobras solution is there's more CapEx in the second half than the first. But I would like to add some other views on that. The number of weeks we've received will increase the standing and really is a (28:20) viable amount on the CapEx for Petróleo Brasileiro, and we did receive a number of them during the course of this first half of the year. But when a new rig arrives, it takes some one, two, three months (28:41) full speed, or the rig itself they are brand new. The team operating the rig is a new team. Normally they are of course experienced people, but there are a mix with new people. And this requires some time to get used to the equipment and adjust to full speed.

So gives us more – I see that more as a matter of a mix of projects being developed than – and the natural roles that happen in the course of time. We are always growing our CapEx. And at the same time last year, we have entered some important projects that requires at the end of the period a higher volume of investment. So that's why we see getting to R$45 billion as feasible or very close to that figure is what we are expecting at this moment.

Thank you. For my second question, if we look back at the time I think a couple of years ago when we start taking about building the deepwater rig in the country, the original expectation is that the 28 rig, that package would start to coming on stream by 2013. Now of course, the first 8 rigs that we are now building that now will be coming on stream until 2015, so there's a vacuum or gap in the 2013 to '14 or maybe even '15 in terms of the number of rigs you need and what is currently already contract. How the company is going to close that gap? And if you're going to soliciting the rig from the market on the existing fleets, when you are going to do it?
Which gap?

No. To some extent the question is obviously when we originally announced the 28 rigs and we've now contracted to build the seven, but at a longer timeframe than was originally discussed, I think the question, Paul, would be is there any gap in the number of rigs that we need over the next three to five years? Is that right, Paul?

That's correct. And if there's – I mean because originally you was assuming that 28 rigs, some of them will start – will be available in 2013, '14 and '15. Now that they won't be available until 2015, so that means that comparing to your initial target, at least there's a gap. Now the question is that gap still exists? Or that has been changed because of your work program change? And if that gap indeed still exists, how you are going to close the gap? Are you going to soliciting rig from the existing fleet market? If you do so, then when you are going to do that?

This gap – what's important here is saying that our current plan is based on the rig target. And the rigs that are being built under contract will be delivered mainly this year next year and 2013. We found rigs that are able to drill up to 3,000 meters of water. We expect to have 39, three nine, by the end of 2013. These rigs are what we need for implementing the plan we have up to 2015/2016. And we have, yes, there were some delays on the first rig of the 28 also we built here, but we did hire rigs from the market that were not in our plan two, three, four years ago. We acquired four or five rigs from the markets that were available, and some of them is already producing and bringing throughout this moment (33:34). So what we have in our plan here according to the availability of the rigs that are in our hands at this moment.

So – and then let me just want to make sure I understand, Almir. So that means that you do not believe there's a gap in your well program in terms of the need of rig – of the additional rig in 2013, 2014 comparing to what you currently already contract?

No, no. There is no more need of extra rigs in 2013, '14 and '15, 2015 or on to implement – to reach the production target of 2020. We need the extra 28 to be delivered, each of them. We have seven under contract, and 21 in bidding process at this moment, but this is for the period beyond 2015.
Okay. Thank you.

The question I had was, are you guys drilling that in the flank of the Franco structure? Or is that at the tip of the Franco structure? [Foreign Language] (35:46 – 35:56). It's the well that has been drilled in the Franco is in the flank of the...
I guess maybe we're really looking for is will the second well help us to close the difference between what Gaffney Cline and what D&M said in their estimate of the reserves in Franco.

Okay. With regard what we have in that is two wells; we needed to drill two wells in Franco. We are drilling the first one. We are doing a pre-drill site today until the end of this year in expectation we will grow until mid of 2012, and then we will drill the second well. We are going to do an extended well test and only then we can declare the commercial visibility. By then we will know the volume that Franco has.

The stock (37:04), I understand mentioned or not was the name of the engineering company is not our main carrier. We are looking at having done what we are obliged to do or is starting the renegotiation of price.

Okay. No, that's fair. Let me then ask you the second question. Barbassa, I wanted to understand, and this comes back to the domestic fuel price discussion, but I just wanted to have a feel from you guys how much do you think you actually have as a cost to bring product into the Brazilian market? So if you have decided to just simply shut down your refineries, I know it's a completely unrealistic assumption, but if you decided to shut down your refineries and just import fuel into Brazil, how much would be the cost on a dollar per barrel basis?
Import oil products into Brazil remains...
The logistics costs associated with bringing product to the Brazilian market, so yeah.
The logistic costs is not only import. It is import and exported today (38:38). What we are saying here is that this cost is around $8 of total in two ways...

And, Gustavo, just to add some comments on this. If you noticed that as you had, this is a very difficult assumption to make because this value (39:08) telling you that we purchased at first, I mean 100,000, 200,000 or 300,000 barrels per day of import. But when you go further if you had, for example, as you said, a shutdown of our refineries, we would probably reach very sooner our limits in terms of the capacity of the terminals, the pipelines, everything. So importing a lot of products above this level of 300,000 or 400,000 barrels per day will actually move new CapEx in terms of adjusting infrastructure, segregating different grades of diesel and gasoline.

So not the end – and besides that, we would also have to import products from countries that are more distant than the lowest, the cheaper market. So importing marginally is a very different business when compared to importing massive volumes of diesel and gasoline and jet fuel. So it would mean all in much more – much higher cost of imports in terms of ships, but also in terms of CapEx, a lot of new things to deal; it's a lot of pipelines to make feasible this operation that would be very risky besides the cost.

Okay. No, guys, the reason I ask, and I just wanted to understand from your perspective, Barbassa. We heard in the Brazil call that there has been no real change to the policy of the company with regards to domestic fuel prices. And as I look at this quarter, there's one thing that's completely novel for me. I think it's the first time ever I've seen Petrobras have an average realization price that is actually lower than the price that you have for the sale just of your oil, okay? In the past even though I could argue that you didn't have a positive spread via Brent, you always were selling more than what your oil was worth. And I just wanted to understand from you guys, is that in anyway a restriction? Is that, I would say, one of those little flags that we should note as being something that triggers a desire from the company to increase prices?

Gustavo, really, this is the first time I start this comparison. What means that this is not an indicator we use internally to such (42:02) a price. The adjustment for us is more related to the expectation of future prices today in the market than what is happening in the marginal supply of the country or supply of our imports.
Okay. That's fair. Thank you, Barbassa.
Okay.
Our next question from Hernán Ladeuix from CLSA. Pardon the pronunciation.

Good morning, everybody. I have a question on the earnings sensitivity. I wonder if you could give us an idea of what would be the earning sensitivity to changes in oil prices after you take into account the regularly fixed prices on the downstream side, the special participation tax and the very large volumes of products imported? I'm asking this because I have the impression that we are near a point where earnings are declining with higher oil prices. I wonder if you can help me understand that? Thank you.

I don't have a figure to tell you, but from all the information I brought and the analysis we have done here we saw even if we don't move the price of gasoline and diesel we have other products, as we have exports, that go to international markets and other products that tax the international price. So there is an increase in the results of the company as we have international price with no change in the diesel and gasoline price in the mass market. In spot – and when you see it on the dollar, you look at the dollar result of the company is that we had an increase in price in the realization price of 15% since last year. And as many other company reports in dollars or when we compare we had an increase in result as well.

I'm asking because that when you take a look at quarter-on-quarter comparisons, you see the upstream making R$1.5 billion more, and the downstream making R$2.2 billion less. I wonder if there's some – probably some unusual factor or there's something more than that?

No, there is one – another factor that is 1% less in production for the E&P. So if they had the same production, probably they would show a higher increase comparing with the downstream, and there were also during these two quarters another important point. We had an increase in our...
Yeah. The inventory effect.

The inventory effect, and definitely we are skewed up (45:50). We have to build our oil and gas inventories here in Brazil due to a stoppage in one of our important pipelines. So we did not – all the oil that was produced by E&P were not sold because we had new production platform that was built for production maintenance.

The production platform maintained on them volume of oil. As they grow huge they have not then the first production accumulating and remain in the platform during the life of the platform, so the buildup of these export – these volumes of oil reduced this volume of stale (47:03) during the second quarter of this year.

Okay. If I can ask the last question. I mean, how confident you are that in a context of oil prices declining, let's say, $20 from current levels you will keep your local prices which are not adjusted by oil prices at the same level?

I don't have a fair try (47:31) to give you. That's our history. In 2008, the price of oil came down from 1.7 through the end of the year – in July. It was 35 at the end of the year. And we kept our price, not only $20, much more than that, $110 change.
Okay. Thank you very much.
You're welcome.

In other words, if you look at the fourth quarter of 2010 where there was additional program maintenance heavier in the second half and you look at the second quarter of 2011, I think what Paula was saying, is that it is about a $1 higher. So the reason that we're giving that it's higher maintenance this quarter – I think you're trying to compare, Paula, the fourth quarter of 2010 with the second quarter of 2011. Is that right?
Yeah precisely, yeah.

Yes, I was wondering, Just for confirmation, you mentioned that the refining the lifting cost were going to continue this high going forward because the (59:24). But in terms of Basin, it's becoming a mature basin. It requires more maintenance and this maintenance is necessary to maintain the production area, the time and the cost of production is higher in the beginning and this is natural for fuels and when a new one comes on stream the average cost reduces.
